sen.j: 龍光院（りょうこういん）は 京都府京都市北区 (京都市)紫野にある、臨済宗大本山大徳寺の仏塔塔頭（たっちゅう）である。
sen.e: Ryoko-in Temple is a sub-temple located within the precinct of Rinzai sect Daihonzan (Head Temple) Daitoku-ji Temple in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Ryoko-in Temple is a sub-temple located within the precinct of Rinzai sect Daihonzan (Head Temple) Daitoku-ji Temple in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Ryoko-in Temple is a sub-temple located within the precinct of Rinzai sect Daihonzan (Head Temple) Daitoku-ji Temple in Murasakino, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 観光客に対しては非公開の方針を貫いており、特別公開の類も一切行われていない。
sen.e: The temple maintains a policy of not opening to sightseers and there are no special openings.
The temple maintains a policy of not opening to sightseers and there are no special openings.
The temple maintains a policy of not opening to sightseers and there are no special openings.

sen.j: 筑前福岡藩主・黒田長政が父・黒田孝高の菩提を弔うために建立。
sen.e: Ryoko-in Temple was constructed by Yoshitaka KURODA to pray for the soul of his father Nagamasa KURODA, lord of the Chikuzen Fukuoka Domain.
Ryoko-in Temple was constructed by Yoshitaka KURODA to pray for the soul of his father Nagamasa KURODA, lord of the Chikuzen Fukuoka Domain.
Ryoko-in Temple was constructed by Nagamasa KURODA, lord of the Chikuzen Fukuoka Domain, to pray for the soul of his father Yoshitaka KURODA.

sen.j: 春屋宗園（しゅんおくそうえん）が没したために事実上の開山となった江月宗玩(こうげつそうがん)は小堀遠州などと親交のあり，在世中には遠州が営んだ孤篷庵が院内にあった。
sen.e: As Shunoku Soen had passed away, the actual kaisan (first chief priest) Kogetsu Sogan was a close friend of Enshu KOBORI, and the Koho-an Temple founded by Enshu stood within Ryoko-in Temple.
As Shunoku Soen had passed away, the actual kaisan (first chief priest) Kogetsu Sogan was a close friend of Enshu KOBORI, and the Koho-an Temple founded by Enshu stood within Ryoko-in Temple.
As Shunoku Soen had passed away, the actual kaisan (first chief priest) Kogetsu Sogan was a close friend of Enshu KOBORI, and the Koho-an Temple founded by Enshu stood within Ryoko-in Temple.

sen.j: かつての龍光院は現在の3倍ほどの敷地だったが、明治の神仏分離令の施行に際して破却の憂き目にあい，現在の姿となった。
sen.e: Ryoko-in Temple once occupied a site three times that of the current site but became devastated as a result of the execution of the edict for the separation of Buddhism and Shinto and reduced to the present scale.

Ryoko-in Temple once occupied a site three times that of the current site but became devastated as a result of the execution of the edict for the separation of Buddhism and Shinto and reduced to the present scale.

Ryoko-in Temple once occupied a site three times that of the current site but became devastated as a result of the execution of the edict for the separation of Buddhism and Shinto in the Meiji period and reduced to the present scale.
sen.cmt: in the Meiji priod 補足

sen.j: 書院(国宝)
sen.e: Shoin (Study Hall) (National Treasure)
Shoin (Study Hall) (National Treasure)
Shoin (Study Hall) (National Treasure)

sen.j: 江戸時代前期（17世紀半ば）に建てられた寄棟造り・杮（こけら）葺きの建物。
sen.e: A yosemune-zukuri (square or rectangular building covered with a hipped roof) building with a shingled roof built during the latter part of the Edo period (mid 17th century).
A yosemune-zukuri (square or rectangular building covered with a hipped roof) building with a shingled roof built during the latter part of the Edo period (mid 17th century).
A yosemune-zukuri (square or rectangular building covered with a hipped roof) building with a shingled roof built during the latter part of the Edo period (mid 17th century).

sen.j: 北西隅に位置する四畳半台目茶室「密庵席（みったんせき）」は書院風茶室の代表例で、元は独立した建物だったとされる。
sen.e: The "Mittanseki" tearoom the size of four tatami mats plus one of less than normal size located in the northwestern corner is highly representative example of the shoin style of tearoom and originally stood as a separate building.

The "Mittanseki" tearoom the size of four tatami mats plus one of less than normal size located in the northwestern corner is highly representative example of the shoin style of tearoom and originally stood as a separate building.

The 'Mittanseki' tearoom the size of four tatami mats plus one of less than normal size located in the northwestern corner is highly representative example of the shoin style of tearoom and originally stood as a separate building.

sen.j: 密庵席は西側の縁側境を明障子、南側の十畳間との境を襖で仕切り、東北側に手前座、北側壁の西寄りに床の間を設ける。
sen.e: To the western edge of the Mittanseki tearoom is an engawa veranda separated by a translucent sliding screen, to the south is a ten tatami mat sized room separated by an opaque sliding screen, to the northeast is the host's tea preparation area, and on the west of the northern wall is an alcove.

To the western edge of the Mittanseki tearoom is an engawa veranda separated by a translucent sliding screen, to the south is a ten tatami mat sized room separated by an opaque sliding screen, to the northeast is the host's tea preparation area, and on the west of the northern wall is an alcove.

To the western edge of the Mittanseki tearoom is an engawa veranda separated by a translucent sliding screen, to the south is a ten tatami mat sized room separated by an opaque sliding screen, to the northeast is the host's tea preparation area, and on the west of the northern wall is an alcove.

sen.j: この床の間とは別に、手前座の南側に奥行の浅い床の間を設ける。
sen.e: In addition to this alcove, a narrow alcove is found on the southern edge of the host's tea preparation area.
In addition to this alcove, a narrow alcove is found on the southern edge of the host's tea preparation area.
In addition to this alcove, a narrow alcove is found on the southern edge of the host's tea preparation area.

sen.j: これは国宝の「密庵墨蹟」の掛け物を掛けるための専用の床である。
sen.e: This alcove was created especially in which to hang the National Treasure-designated "Mitsuan Calligraphy" hanging scroll.
This alcove was created especially in which to hang the National Treasure-designated "Mitsuan Calligraphy" hanging scroll.
This alcove was created especially in which to hang the National Treasure-designated 'Mitsuan Calligraphy' hanging scroll.

sen.e: Main Hall (Important Cultural Property)

sen.j: 書院の西に建つ。
sen.e: Stands to the west of the shoin.
Stands to the west of the shoin.

sen.j: 慶安2年（1649年）の建立。
sen.e: Constructed in 1649.
Constructed in 1649.
Constructed in 1649.

sen.j: 寄棟造檜皮葺き。
sen.e: A yosemune-zukuri (square or rectangular building covered with a hipped roof) building with a Japanese cypress covered roof.
A yosemune-zukuri (square or rectangular building covered with a hipped roof) building with a Japanese cypress covered roof.

Bankaro Corridor

sen.j: 本堂と同じく慶安2年（1649年）の建立。
sen.e: Constructed in 1649 - the same year as the main hall.
Constructed in 1649 - the same year as the main hall.
Constructed in 1649 - the same year as the main hall.

sen.j: 本堂と書院の間の南方に位置する廊下である。
sen.e: A corridor located to the south between the main hall and shoin.
A corridor located to the south between the main hall and shoin.

sen.j: 兜門（重要文化財）
sen.e: Kabuto-mon Gate
Kabuto-mon Gate
Kabuto-mon Gate (Important Cultural Property)

sen.j: 龍光院の表門で、檜皮葺きの平唐門である。
sen.e: Ryoko-in Temple's front gate with a Japanese cypress bark covered roof and undulating bargeboards on each gable end.
Ryoko-in Temple's front gate with a Japanese cypress bark covered roof and undulating bargeboards on each gable end.

sen.j: 書院
sen.e: Shoin (Study Hall)
Shoin (Study Hall)

sen.j: 密庵咸傑墨蹟（附 千利休消息）
sen.e: Mittan Kanketsu Bokuseki (Designation Includes a Letter Written by SEN no Rikyu)
Mittan Kanketsu Bokuseki (Designation Includes a Letter Written by SEN no Rikyu)
Mittan Kanketsu Bokuseki (Designation Includes a Letter Written by SEN no Rikyu)

sen.j: 中国・宋代の禅僧・密庵咸傑（みったんかんけつ）の現存唯一の墨蹟とされる（「墨蹟」は禅宗高僧の筆跡を指す用語）。
sen.e: Believed to be the only surviving work of calligraphy by Chinese Song Dynasty Zen monk Mi'an Xianjie ('Mittan Kanketsu' in Japanese) ('bokuseki' refers to the handwriting of a high-ranking Zen priest).

Believed to be the only surviving work of calligraphy by Chinese Song Dynasty Zen monk Mi'an Xianjie ('Mittan Kanketsu' in Japanese) ('bokuseki' refers to the handwriting of a high-ranking Zen priest).

Believed to be the only surviving work of calligraphy by Chinese Song Dynasty Zen monk Mi'an Xianjie ('Mittan Kanketsu' in Japanese) ('bokuseki' refers to the handwriting of a high-ranking Zen priest).

sen.j: この法語は禅林（禅宗の寺院）はもとより千利休をはじめとする多くの茶人より多大な尊敬が払われ，龍光院書院内の茶室・密庵席には特にこの一幅のみを飾るための密庵床（みったんどこ）という場所が設けられている。
sen.e: This Buddhist sermon was greatly respected at Zenrin (a Zen temple) by numerous tea ceremony masters including SEN no Rikyu, and the Mittan-doko (Mittan alcove) was created within the shoin at Ryoko-in Temple especially in which to hang this scroll.

This Buddhist sermon was greatly respected at Zenrin (a Zen temple) by numerous tea ceremony masters including SEN no Rikyu, and the Mittan-doko (Mittan alcove) was created within the shoin at Ryoko-in Temple especially in which to hang this scroll.

This Buddhist sermon was greatly respected at Zenrin (a Zen temple) and also by numerous tea ceremony masters including SEN no Rikyu, and the Mittan-doko (Mittan alcove) was created within the Mittanseki tearoom of the shoin at Ryoko-in Temple especially in which to hang this scroll.
sen.cmt: and also補足the Mittanseki tearoom補足

sen.j: 附指定の利休の添状は墨蹟とともに伝来してきたものである。
sen.e: The accompanying letter included within the designation arrived at the temple along with the bokuseki.
The accompanying letter included within the designation arrived at the temple along with the bokuseki.
The accompanying letter by Rikyu included within the designation arrived at the temple along with the bokuseki.

sen.j: 竺仙梵僊墨蹟
sen.e: Jikusen Bonsen Bokuseki
Jikusen Bonsen Bokuseki
Jikusen Bonsen Bokuseki

sen.j: およそ20年間にわたり日本禅林の振興に力を注ぎ，後の五山文学(鎌倉末期～室町時代の京都五山の禅僧の手になる漢詩文)興隆の基礎を築いた中国・元の禅僧である竺仙梵僊（じくせんぼんせん）の墨蹟である。
sen.e: Calligraphy by Chinese Yuan Dynasty Zen monk Zhuxian Fanxian ('Jikusen Bonsen' in Japanese) who worked for around 20 years to promote the Japan Zenrin temple and the later Gozan literature (Chinese poetry composed by Zen monks of the five great Zen temples of Kyoto from end of the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period).

Calligraphy by Chinese Yuan Dynasty Zen monk Zhuxian Fanxian ('Jikusen Bonsen' in Japanese) who worked for around 20 years to promote the Japan Zenrin temple and the later Gozan literature (Chinese poetry composed by Zen monks of the five great Zen temples of Kyoto from end of the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period).

Calligraphy by Chinese Yuan Dynasty Zen monk Zhuxian Fanxian ('Jikusen Bonsen' in Japanese) who worked for around 20 years to promote the Japan Zenrin temple and the later Gozan literature (Chinese poetry composed by Zen monks of the five great Zen temples of Kyoto from end of the Kamakura period to the Muromachi period).

sen.j: 現存する竺仙梵僊の墨蹟中で大字・大幅であり、彼の闊達な書法を示す代表作といえる。
sen.e: Of the surviving calligraphy works by Jikusen Bonsen, this piece can be said to be highly representative of his bold style with both large characters and width.
Of the surviving calligraphy works by Jikusen Bonsen, this piece can be said to be highly representative of his bold style with both large characters and width.
Of the surviving calligraphy works by Jikusen Bonsen, this piece can be said to be highly representative of his bold style with both large characters and width.

sen.e: Diamond Sutra Written by Daikaku Zenji

sen.e: Yohen Tenmoku tea bowl

sen.j: 中国・南宋時代。
sen.e: Dating from the Chinese Southern Song Dynasty.
Dating from the Chinese Southern Song Dynasty.
Dating from the Chinese Southern Song Dynasty.

sen.j: 福建省の建窯の製品。
sen.e: Made in Jianyao, Fujian Province.
Made in Jianyao, Fujian Province.
Made in Jianyao, Fujian Province.

sen.j: 曜変天目は黒釉の表面に大小の斑紋が現れ、虹のようにきらめくものである。
sen.e: Yohen Tenmoku referes to articles on which large and small spots appear on the black glaze on the surface to create a rainbow-like sparkle.
Yohen Tenmoku referes to articles on which large and small spots appear on the black glaze on the surface to create a rainbow-like sparkle.
Yohen Tenmoku refers to articles on which large and small spots appear on the black glaze on the surface to create a rainbow-like sparkle.

sen.j: 曜変天目の遺品はきわめて稀少で、世界で日本のみに伝世し、本碗を含め3碗ないし4碗が伝世するのみとされている。
sen.e: Yohen Tenmoku items are extremely rare and only handed down from generation to generation in Japan, with only three or four being passed down including this bowl.
Yohen Tenmoku items are extremely rare and only handed down from generation to generation in Japan, with only three or four being passed down including this bowl.
Yohen Tenmoku items are extremely rare and only handed down from generation to generation in Japan, with only three or four being passed down including this bowl.

sen.j: 有栖川宮家墓所
sen.e: Grave of the Arisugawa-no-Miya Family
Grave of the Arisugawa-no-Miya Family
Grave of the Arisugawa-no-Miya Family

sen.j: 龍光院は明治維新まで高松宮・有栖川宮家の菩提寺であり、初代・高松宮好仁親王から第8代・有栖川宮韶仁親王までの歴代墓所がある。
sen.e: Until the Meiji Restoration, Ryoko-in Temple served as an ancestral temple of the Takamatsu-no-Miya and Arisugawa-no-Miya families and has the graves of successive family heads from the first generation Imperial Prince Yoshihito Tamatsu-no-Miya to the eighth generation Imperial Prince Tsunahito Arisugawa-no-Miya.

Until the Meiji Restoration, Ryoko-in Temple served as an ancestral temple of the Takamatsu-no-Miya and Arisugawa-no-Miya families and has the graves of successive family heads from the first generation Imperial Prince Yoshihito Tamatsu-no-Miya to the eighth generation Imperial Prince Tsunahito Arisugawa-no-Miya.

Until the Meiji Restoration, Ryoko-in Temple served as an ancestral temple of the Takamatsu-no-Miya and Arisugawa-no-Miya families and has the graves of successive family heads from the first generation Imperial Prince Yoshihito Takamatsu-no-Miya to the eighth generation Imperial Prince Tsunahito Arisugawa-no-Miya.

sen.j: （ただし、第2代・良仁親王は践祚して後西天皇となったため、龍光院ではなく泉涌寺に葬られている）
sen.e: However, the second generation Imperial Prince Yoshihito ascended to the throne to become Emperor Gosai and is therefore buried at Senyu-ji Temple as opposed to Ryoko-in Temple.
However, the second generation Imperial Prince Yoshihito ascended to the throne to become Emperor Gosai and is therefore buried at Senyu-ji Temple as opposed to Ryoko-in Temple.
However, the second generation Imperial Prince Yoshihito ascended to the throne to become the Emperor Gosai and is therefore buried at Senyu-ji Temple as opposed to Ryoko-in Temple.

sen.j: JR京都駅より京都市営バス・大徳寺前（約30分）下車、徒歩
sen.e: Take the Kyoto City Bus from JR Kyoto Station to "Daitoku-ji mae" bus stop (approximately 30 minutes) and walk.
Take the Kyoto City Bus from JR Kyoto Station to "Daitoku-ji mae" bus stop (approximately 30 minutes) and walk.
